metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Owners of Steamship El Madina

facts.text: Respondents were owners of steamship El Madina requisitioned by Government during last world war and lost by enemy action on March 16, 1944.
Government paid compensation: Rs. 20,00,000 on July 17, 1944; Rs. 23,00,000 on December 22, 1944; Rs. 33,333 on August 10, 1946.
Original cost of ship Rs. 24,95,016; written down value at commencement of year of account Rs. 15,68,484; difference Rs. 9,26,532 represents depreciation deductions allowed year after year.
Total compensation exceeded original cost; respondents recouped all depreciation deductions.
Year of assessment 1946-47; controversy whether Rs. 9,26,532 liable to be included in total income.

Respondents contended before income-tax authorities that per Board of Revenue direction for Excess Profits Tax Act, compensation deemed received on April 16, 1944 (within 30 days of loss), not in year July 1, 1944 to June 30, 1945.
Appellate Tribunal on July 15, 1953 held Board's concession limited to excess profits tax; material date when compensation actually received in year of account; amount includible.
Tribunal on February 9, 1954 referred question: whether Rs. 9,26,532 properly included in assessee's total income for 1946-47.

Bombay High Court (Chagla CJ, Tendolkar J) on September 13, 1954 overruled preliminary objection; held 4th proviso to s.10(2)(vii) introduced by Income-tax Amendment Act VIII of 1946 (effective May 4, 1946) not applicable as liability determined on April 1, 1946; answered negative.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 9,26,532 was properly included in the assessee company's total income computed for the assessment year 1946-47.
Whether in a reference under s.66(1) of Income-tax Act 1922, the High Court can consider a question of law not raised before or dealt with by the Tribunal.
Whether the 4th proviso to s.10(2)(vii) introduced by Act VIII of 1946 effective May 4, 1946 applies to assessment year 1946-47 where liability crystallizes on April 1, 1946.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court had no jurisdiction to consider applicability of proviso to s.10(2)(vii) as not raised before Tribunal or arising out of its order; could not be raised first time in reference.
Proviso to s.10(2)(vii) applies; amount is profits of previous year in which moneys received.

respondent_arguments.text: Compensation deemed received April 16, 1944 per Board direction for Excess Profits Tax; not in year of account.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 4 Schedule II Excess Profits Tax Act 1940

respondent_arguments.text: 4th proviso to s.10(2)(vii) not applicable as introduced May 4, 1946 after April 1, 1946; not retrospective; question wide enough to cover this.
Any question of law arising on facts found by Tribunal arises out of its order; not limited to those argued before it.

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction under s.66 is special/advisory; question of law must arise out of Tribunal's order, meaning raised before or dealt with by Tribunal (deemed dealt with if raised but not expressly). New questions not arising on findings alone cannot be entertained.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Stating compendiously, only question raised before or decided by Tribunal arises out of its order.

court_reasoning.text: Referred question 'whether Rs.9,26,532 properly included in total income for 1946-47' sufficiently wide to include aspect of proviso's applicability; different aspects/approaches to same question permissible without being new question.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question may be complex with multiple aspects; s.66(1) does not limit to aspects argued before Tribunal if within framework.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso not retrospective; came into force May 4, 1946 after liability crystallized April 1, 1946; cannot apply.

Shah J (separate): Tribunal erroneously assumed proviso in force; question of its applicability arises out of order as Tribunal relied on it; High Court jurisdiction to decide questions arising from order, not limited to arguments before Tribunal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question arises out of order even if not argued before Tribunal if founded on its decision.

holdings.text: Question of law under s.66(1) arises out of Tribunal order only if raised before it or dealt with/decided by it; not merely from findings.
Referred question wide enough to permit contention on proviso's non-applicability as aspect of whether amount properly included.
Rs.9,26,532 not properly included in total income for AY 1946-47 as 4th proviso to s.10(2)(vii) not in force on April 1, 1946.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. Mtt. Ar. S. Ar. Arunachalam Chettiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction under s.66 conditional on question arising out of order under s.33(4).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay South v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Referred question of sufficient amplitude covers new point if no objection to reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: New Jehangir Vakil Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: s.66(4) limited to questions arising out of order referable under s.66(1)/(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Kusumben D. Mahadevia v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court cannot decide different question not arising out of Tribunal order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Zoraster Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Supplemental statement under s.66(4) confined to referred question; new questions not allowed.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. Abboy Chetty and Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Question arises out of order only if raised before Tribunal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madanlal Dharnidharka v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay view allowing questions on facts found rejected.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso deems excess compensation over depreciation as profits; reference procedure limits questions to those arising out of Tribunal order.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Amendment Act, 1946 (VIII of 1946)
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced proviso effective May 4, 1946; not retrospective.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Board direction deemed compensation received within 30 days of loss for excess profits tax purposes only.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the Revenue's appeal with costs, upholding Bombay High Court's decision that Rs. 9,26,532 was not properly included in assessee's total income for assessment year 1946-47 as the 4th proviso to s.10(2)(vii) was not in force on April 1, 1946.

key_quotes.text: Stating the position compendiously, it is only a question that has been raised before or decided by the Tribunal that could be held to arise out of its order.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of 'question of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal' under s.66(1).

key_quotes.text: The jurisdiction of a court in a reference under s.66 is a special one... It acts purely in an advisory capacity.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies advisory nature of High Court jurisdiction in income-tax references.

key_quotes.text: Proviso in terms, it is not retrospective, and we cannot import into its construction matters which are ad extra legis.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds 4th proviso to s.10(2)(vii) not applicable to AY 1946-47.
